title: Protests Work! Make your voice heard!

articles.title: 4 Officers Fired for Mudering George Floyd
articles.description: 4 Officers were fired for the murder of George Floyd on May 26th by the Minneapolis Police Department.

articles.title: University of Minneapolis Cancels Contract with Minneapolis PD
articles.description: On the 28th of May the University of Minnesota announced that it would not contract with the Minneapolis Police department after the death of George Floyd. This would affect football games, concerts, and ceremonies.

articles.title: ATU Local 1005 refuses to bring police officers to the protests, or transport arrested protesters
articles.description: On the 28th of May the Amalgamated Transit Union released a statement saying thy would not transport police officers to the protests or transport arrested protestors.

articles.title: Officer Chauvin who killed George Floyd arrested
articles.description: On the 28th of May the Amalgamated Transit Union released a statement saying thy would not transport police officers to the protests or transport arrested protestors.

articles.title: Louisville Mayor suspends "no-knock" warrants in response to police's 3/12 #BreonnaTaylor killing and subsequent protests
articles.description: On the 29th of May 2020, Louisville Mayor Greg Fischer announced at least temporary halt on no-knock warrants. A no-knock warrant had previously led to the police shooting of Breonna Taylor, an emergency room tech, former EMT, and person of color.

articles.title: US Embassies across Africa condemn police murder of George Floyd
articles.description: In a rare and extraordinary move US Embassies all across the African Continent condemned the killing of George Flord by police. Embassies involved: Kenya, Uganda, Tanzania, DR Congo

articles.title: MN AG Ellison Takes Over Prosecution of the Officers Involved in Geroge Floyd Case
articles.description: IMinnesota Attorney General was asked to assist and lead the prosecution of the officers involved in the murder for George Floyd

The New York Times on Sunday announced the resignation of its editorial page editor, James Bennet. The announcement comes four days after the newspaper published a controversial op-ed from Sen. Tom Cotton (R.-Ark.) that called for military intervention in U.S. cities wracked by protests over police violence.

articles.description: The University of Alabama took down memorials to confederate soldiers and removed plaques honoring students who served in the COnfederate Army and Student Cadet Corps. A school offical said theyäd be displayed in a more appropriate historial setting.

NY Gov. Cuomo Signs Police Reform Legislation into Law
articles.description: Repeal Section 50(a) of the Civil Rights Law which provides additional protection for police officers, firefighters, and corrections officers. Create Office of Special Investigation within AGs office to investigate deaths caused by police officer and peace officer. Clarifies that a person not under arrest or in custody has the right ot record police activity, devices used to record, and recordings. Prohibits use of chokeholds by law enforcement and establishes it as a crime. Create an misconduct investigateive office to sutdy, audit, and recommend changes to operations, policies programs and practices of law enforcement. Require courts to compile and publish racial and other demographic data on all low level offenses. Mandates body cameras for officers. Require officers to report within six hours discharging of weapons whether on or off duty.

SC Supreme Court Revokes No-Knock Warrants.
articles.description: "Magistrates issue the majority of search warrants in South Carolina. A recent survey of magistrates revealed that most do not understand the gravity of no-knock warrants and do not discern the heightened requirements for issuing a no-knock warrant. It further appears that no-knock search warrants are routinely issued upon request without further inquiry. In recognition of the dangers that the execution of no-knock warrants present to law enforcement and members of the public, and in order to ensure that these warrants are issued based upon the proper constitutional and statutory criteria, I FIND it necessary to address the issuance of no-knock search warrants by circuit and summary court judges statewide. Pursuant to Article V, Section 4 of the South Carolina Constitution,IT IS ORDERED that a moratorium upon the issuance of no-knock warrants by all circuit and summary court judges of this state take effect immediately and remain in effect until instruction is provided to circuit and summary court judges statewide as to the criteria to be used to determine whether a requested no-knock warrant should be issued. This instruction will be provided by the South Carolina Judicial Branch."
